fields.headline: Christmas 2009: film
fields.bodyText: Me and Orson Welles Zac Efron proves he's ready to graduate from high school in Richard Linklater's latest. He plays Richard, a callow young fellow in the 1930s, who manages to persuade no less a figure than Orson Welles to give him a small role in the legendary Mercury Theatre production of Julius Caesar. Released on 4 December. Where the Wild Things Are The famous illustrated children's book about a strange wonderland populated by marvellous, scary creatures with fur and horns has been fleshed out into a feature film by Spike Jonze, where a little boy runs away to this mythical land and installs himself as their king. Released on 11 December. Avatar James "Titanic" Cameron returns to mainstream movie-making, bringing us this state-of-the-art spectacular. Sam Worthington plays Jake, a disabled former combat soldier who is recreated as an avatar – a humanoid form that can survive on the distant planet of Pandora. Released on 17 December. The Red Shoes This 1948 classic has been lovingly restored, and experiencing the entrancing and yet disturbing film is a must: it's a gorgeous, almost hallucinatory experience. Anton Walbrook is the martinet ballet impresario, Moira Shearer is his lovely young star, and the ballet of the Red Shoes symbolises the terrible demands of art. Released on 11 December. Nowhere Boy Sam Taylor-Wood makes a confident leap from art to conventional movie-making with this accomplished biopic about the early years of John Lennon. The film stars Taylor-Wood's partner, 19-year-old Aaron Johnson, in the lead role. Released on 25 December. The Limits of Control This is a mouthwatering prospect for fans of Jim Jarmusch: an elegant, pared-down, enigmatic movie that appears to be about a contract killer – or is it? Isaach de Bankolé plays a mysterious man who arrives at a Spanish airport and makes contact with various Jarmusch regulars including Bill Murray and Tilda Swinton. Released on 11 December.
